awd_titl_txt: University of Hawaii R/V Kilo Moana Oceanographic Instrumentation
awd_abstract_narration:
Kilo Moana is a 186-foot, general-purpose research vessel built in 2002 and operated by the University of Hawaii under a charter party agreement with the Office of Naval Research (ONR). The vessel is part of the US Academic Research Fleet (ARF) and is supported by the University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS). Ship time is made available to academic researchers funded by the NSF, ONR, NOAA, NASA, and other federal and state agencies. 

The University of Hawaii requests funds for purchase of the following Oceanographic Instrumentation:

1)	OS 38 ADCP	$188,445
2)	GP Oceanographic Winch	$304,750
3)	Sound Velocity Profiler	$14,080
		$507,275
Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 13-589). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF).  The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The University of Hawaii (UH) supports a research vessel that provides platforms for innovative research in the fields of oceanography, marine biology, geology and atmospheric science.  The ability to accurately assess subsurface currents is fundamental to the interpretation of properties that characterize water masses analyzed by sensor suites such as CTD systems. The R/V Kilo Moana is equipped with two hull-mounted ADCPs (Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers): WH300 and OS38. The OS38 (Ocean Surveyor 38kHz) is the Kilo Moana’s deep water ADCP and collects oceanic current data from depths of 100m to 1200m.  The vessel is also equipped with two seabed mapping sonars.  Measurements of both sound velocity and temperature (SVT) are required as close as possible to the Kilo Moana transducers to achieve accurate multibeam seafloor mapping.

The funds provided were used to replace the Kilo Moana's 19-year-old OS38, which had reached the end of its productive life.  The OS38 is one of the most important components of the Kilo Moana’s underway system and, when operational, is continually collecting scientifically meaningful data around the Pacific Ocean.  The ship’s crew uses data from the OS38 to ensure that instrument arrays and cables stay at a safe distance from hull and propulsion.  Science teams routinely utilize ADCP data to predict how deep-water currents will affect free floating arrays. This enables the determination of safe and appropriate deployment areas as well as estimates of how far arrays might travel during their in-water time.  Scientists also use the OS38 to estimate drift ranges and distances for instruments and weights dropped from the ship to the seafloor. This aids in pinpointing a given package’s landing position on the seabed.  Furthermore, ROV operators utilize deep-water data from the OS38 to prepare for conditions at project depths.  

Additional funds were provided to obtain two new SVT sensors to replace existing ones that were also reaching the end of their functional life and no longer were able to be calibrated by the vendor.


Last Modified: 07/30/2024
Modified by: James S Ferguson
